Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add a standardised entry for clarifying pricing/limitations for commercial packages." (#8427) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
It is not easy to distinguish whether the package is free or commercial just seeing the package description UI in Visual Studio. I would have to visit the company's website and look for pages that has pricing or purchasing information, and other pages for limitations. Repeating this for tens of results is annoying.

See an example below. Can you tell this is free or paid? When I tried to load a PDF after adding this, it showed some sort of error message (in broken English, so it was difficult what exactly it was saying) that this free version can only open PDF's < 4MB in size. The price was about $900. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10900489/108646187-6202e380-74f8-11eb-9f17-532143041526.png)

### Describe the solution you'd like
Why not have an entry like the following, as with the current "Version:", "Author(s)", "License:", etc?
Pricing: Free, $900 annual, $1000 one-time, etc
Free version limitation: Can't open PDF < 4MB in size, 30-day trial, watermark, etc. 

### Additional context
Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NU1004 should contain more actionable information " (#7696) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Currently the message when a lock file is inconsistent with the project is the following: 

> 2019-01-15T05:13:49.0324738Z ##[error]src\NuGet.Clients\NuGet.PackageManagement.PowerShellCmdlets\NuGet.PackageManagement.PowerShellCmdlets.csproj(0,0): Error NU1004: The packages lock file is inconsistent with the project dependencies so restore can't be run in locked mode. Please disable RestoreLockedMode MSBuild property or pass explicit --force-evaluate flag to run restore to update the lock file.

Ideally this message contains information about what NuGet thinks changed. 
Couple of different options causing NU1004. 

* PackageReference add/remove
* PackageReference update
* ProjectReference add/remove
* ProjectReference transitive packages add/remove/update
* TFM change. 

The reason for this is that I'm seeing lots of failures in https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2331449, but it doesn't necessarily tell us what's wrong. 

//cc @jainaashish @anangaur

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "How are fallback paths populated into nuget.g.props for NuGetPackageFolders?  " (#10580) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We have one user getting an unexpected Xamarian path added to the list of NuGetPackageFolders in his *.nuget.g.props files when running dotnet.exe restore (using version 5.0.102), for which we have not been able to track down the reason.  

Specifically our environment has a nuget.config that clears all earlier setting and only adds very specific enlistment known paths (globalPackagesFolder is set, while RepositoryPath is cleared).  We also sandbox environment variables that are allowed to pass through to the processes being run (so things like NUGET_PACKAGES are not set).  

Most folks just have globalPackagesFolder and a NuGetFallbackFolder under the sdk folder, though the user above has a third folder (before the sdk location) for C:\Microsoft\Xamarin\NuGet\ that we want to remove from that list.  We need to understand how that's getting added as a first step.  

This matters for our team as we use BuildXL to distribute our builds, and the extra path is being read by dotnet.exe causing mismatches to what is statically declared for our BuildXL graph.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Launch NuGet Package Explorer from NuGet.org" (#10591) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: It would be very useful if there was a link which uses custom scheme to launch [NuGet Package Explorer](https://github.com/NuGetPackageExplorer/NuGetPackageExplorer) with the current package to load.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget restore is failed in Windows build." (#10586) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
---
**Issue moved from dotnet/core#5881**
- Please respond to @vsafonkin.

---

_From @vsafonkin on Tuesday, January 26, 2021 2:38:36 PM_

<!--This is just a template - feel free to delete any and all of it and replace as appropriate. If you're not sure of an answer, just skip it. We'll help you! -->

### Description

* Sometimes `dotnet build` command is failed on Nuget restore step. The error:
```
error NU1101: Unable to find package <package name>. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Microsoft Visual Studio Offline Packages
```
* repro: https://github.com/vsafonkin/ualbion/runs/1726489951?check_suite_focus=true

### Configuration

* Which version of .NET is the code running on? 5.0.101
* What OS and version, and for Linux, what distro? Windows
* What is the architecture (x64, x86, ARM, ARM64)? x64

It can be fixed either with creation `nuget.config` file with nuget sources list or running `dotnet nuget locals all --clear` before build.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PowerShell with .net core 5.0 in Ubuntu 20.4 - Unable to resolve package reference ''." (#10583) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm using PowerShell with .net core 5.0 in Ubuntu 20.4; but I'm having an issue importing nuget libraries using the Install-Package command.

The machine is in a locked down environment with no access to the outside world so nuget pacakages are stored on a fileshare.

This works fine on Windows Devices, but the Ubuntu device is complaining.

The specific command I'm using is:
Install-Package -Source /mnt/share/DotNetCorePackages -Name system.xml.xpath.xmldocument -SkipDependencies

The error message I'm receiving is:
Install-Package: Unable to resolve package reference ''.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget keeps redownloading packaget to %USERPROFILE%\nuget\packages even when I changed globalPackagesFolder in my nuget.config" (#10561) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I have configured my `nuget.config` to use another drive as a local repository but it still keeps installing in the `%USERPROFILE%\nuget\packages`:

Here is my configuration folder for my global `nuget,config`:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
	<config>
		<add key="globalPackagesFolder" value="D:\dotNet\nuget-packages" />
		<add key="repositoryPath" value="D:\dotNet\nuget-packages" />
	</config>
</configuration>
```

Does this not work for global configurations? `nuget,config`

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Fine-tuning the output of a dev-dependency nuget package reference" (#10512) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

* Using: Visual Studio 2019 v16.8.3 Nuget Window.

I've noticed that whenever I add a "dev-only" Nuget package to a project, it is rendered this way in the target csproj (using GitVersion.MsBuild as an example, but seems to be the case for all dev-only packages I'm aware of):

```xml
<PackageReference Include="GitVersion.MsBuild" Version="5.6.4">
  <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
  <IncludeAssets>runtime; build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
</PackageReference>
```

There are cases where I'd rather have this (notice that 'runtime' is gone from the included assets):

```xml
<PackageReference Include="GitVersion.MsBuild" Version="5.6.4">
  <PrivateAssets>all</PrivateAssets>
  <IncludeAssets>build; native; contentfiles; analyzers; buildtransitive</IncludeAssets>
</PackageReference>
```

I wonder if there is a means, from the nuget author perspective to obtain the latter result? I'm aware of the `<DevelopmentDependency>`, but how can one fine tune the way the nuget will be referenced in target projects?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet restore failing on .NET 5 for Debian-based OSes" (#49) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey Everyone,

Our preliminary investigation shows that .NET 5 restore is broken for Debian-based operating systems including Docker thus resulting in error messages like:

```
error NU3037: Package 'System.Memory 4.5.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The author primary signature validity period has expired.
```

### [Debian Versions](https://www.debian.org/releases/)
- We're currently aware that Debian 10 ("buster") and earlier versions are affected. ❌
- We do know that Debian testing ("bullseye") and later are not affected. ✔

This is because of an [issue reported](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=962596) in the `ca-certificates` package in which the root CA being used are not trusted and must be installed manually due to [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues). Because this issue has been resolved recently in version 20210119 of this package, it is not available in a Debian version as provided in `dotnet-docker` for `buster-slim` today.

## Workarounds

- Manually update the [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/ca-certificates) package to version 20210119 including a `bullseye` or later version.
- Consider using a different Debian-based Docker image such as `alpine` or `focal`.
 
## Solution

We're currently working to update the `dotnet-docker`'s `buster-slim` image to update the `ca-certificates` package to 20210119 that resolves this issue. We are however currently verifying this is a viable solution with no large diffs between the `buster` and `bullseye` releases.

Additionally, the `ca-certificates` package is due to be installed in the Debian FTP archive which will promote this fix to the `buster` release in the next few days to which an updated `buster-slim` image will be prepared and released when available.

## Stay Updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We'll continue to update the discussion at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10491.
- We will also continue posting updates on https://status.nuget.org and on Twitter @NuGet.
